instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No sound from speakers after liquid spill repair.
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board was liquid damaged. Corrosion around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6400</CHIP>. Would not power on. Replaced a few damaged components around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> fixed the power problem. Now no audio through speakers. Audio through headphone jack works. <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> had corrosion underneath it. Replaced <CHIP>U6400</CHIP>, problem persists. Can change volume, switches from headphones to internal speakers when headphones unplugged. 

I have traced everything I can think of following schematic and all components around <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> seem fine. 

Don't know where to go from here, any help is appreciated!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No sound from speakers after liquid spill repair.
threads.message:
Check power rails for <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6500</CHIP>/50.
Also check <SIGNAL>AUD_SPKRAMP_RESET_L</SIGNAL> level; must be high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No sound from speakers after liquid spill repair.
threads.message:
Power rails seem fine, <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> is 1.8v and PPBUS is 12.59 at all 4 amp chips. 

<SIGNAL>AUD_SPKRAMP_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 1.8v.

One thing I noticed is. <SIGNAL>VREF_AMP_WL</SIGNAL> is 2v while booting and drops to 0 when booted up. Can't find datasheet on MAX98706, any idea what <SIGNAL>VREF_AMP_WL</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>VREF_AMP_TL</SIGNAL> etc do?

I'm really lost on this one

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No sound from speakers after liquid spill repair.
threads.message: Remove <CHIP>U6400</CHIP> and check for sound on the other channels.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No sound from speakers after liquid spill repair.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No sound from speakers after liquid spill repair.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No sound from speakers after liquid spill repair.
threads.message: Don't have speakers for this. I did test them and all 4 are 4 ohms. Also tried just the right speaker and just the left. I feel like I'm missing something stupidly obvious.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No sound from speakers after liquid spill repair.
threads.message:
I remember someone else thread where tried new non-working chinese speakers.
That's the reason I asked to test with known good working speakers.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> No sound from speakers after liquid spill repair.
threads.message: Customer didn't want to wait any more, took it as is. Guess we'll never know what the problem was.
